Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: 2D Nanoelectronic Devices Integrated with Nanofluidic Structures for Biosensing Applications

Division.LongName: Div Of Electrical, Commun & Cyber Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
The ability to detect and quantify low-abundance biomolecules is critical for clinical diagnostics and drug development. For example, such ability can be used for early-stage cancer diagnosis. Surface plasmon resonance is the standard method for such analysis, but it still suffers from drawbacks such as low sensitivity, poor detection limit, and slow analysis process. These limitations motivate the efforts to create new nanoscale electronic biosensors for realizing efficient, label-free, multiplexing biomolecule quantification at low detection limits. The work described in this proposal aims at constructing a new biosensor by integrating emerging two-dimensional (2D) nanoelectronic materials into nano/microfluidic structures. Such a 2D-material-integrated nanofluidic biosensor, if successfully realized, will greatly advance the capability for illness-related biomarker detection and quantification. The work proposed here holds significant potential for realizing new cost/time-effective immunoassay chips that can address global needs for new capabilities for diagnosis and stratification of diseases and US industrial competitiveness. Beyond advancing fundamental academic research capabilities, the proposed education/research-integrated program will provide relevant knowledge and technical skills to a broad range of people, including K-12 students/educators, undergraduates, graduates, as well as students from underrepresented and minority groups. Specifically, the proposed education/outreach program will include a new after-school program for instructing K-12 students to learn basic knowledge related to microfluidic/electronic-integrated biosensors; extending the collaboration with academic programs at the University of Michigan to provide research opportunities for undergraduates; introducing new topics related to nanofluidics and nanoelectronics into graduate/undergraduate courses.

The proposed device-oriented research seeks to leverage superior electronic/structural properties of 2D materials and unique electrokinetics in nanofluidic devices for enabling low-abundance biomolecule detection at single-molecule levels. To realize this goal, the PI will overcome a series of challenges related to nanoelectronics, nanofluidics, and biosensing. Specifically, (i) create a nanofabrication method capable of integrating nano/microfluidic structures with nanoscale 2D transistors and producing large device arrays, therefore enabling the device miniaturization and multiplexing capability required for the envisaged bio-assays. (ii) Create a biofunctionalization route for realizing the selective functionalization of nanoelectronic sensors and an electrokinetic approach for efficiently transporting/concentrating target molecules toward the sensing areas, which are critical for preventing non-specific adsorption and obtaining a low limit-of-detection required for low-abundance molecule quantification. Non-specific adsorption will be further suppressed through using specific blocking buffers and optimizing nanofluidic architectures. (iii) Obtain a comprehensive understanding of the complex interactions between nanoelectronic and nanofluidic characteristics of the proposed device, which include electrokinetic transport rates of biomolecules toward sensors, effects of nanofluidic environments on biomolecule concentration distributions, dynamic behaviors of transistor parameters in response to bioconjugation processes, and relationship between the dissociation constant of an analyte-receptor pair and the sensor's detection limit/specificity. (iv) Develop multiplexed device arrays capable of rapidly determining multiple biomolecule concentrations. The proposed biosensor, if successfully created, can firstly serve as a generic device platform for analyzing a broad range of molecular interactions. Especially, it can be used for measuring the affinities and kinetics of various analyte-receptor pair interactions with sensitivities down to femtomolar concentrations (or single-molecule-level detection limits). Such knowledge will greatly advance the understanding of complex cellular events, such as the development of cancers and immune-responses. The large arrays of the proposed biosensors would eventually allow for rapid (minute-scale sample-to-result elapsed times), highly precise (single-molecule-level detection limits) immunoassay for clinical diagnostics. The detection principle of the proposed biosensor is completely electrical and does not need any off-chip optics required for conventional fluorescence-based assays. This will enable stand-alone device capability required for point-of-care applications.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The scientific ability to detect and precisely quantify low-abundance biomarker molecules is important for clinical diagnostics and drug development. Especially, during the current COVID-19 pandemic, such biosensing capabilities have been becoming more and more demanding.  In addition, such ability can be also implemented for early-stage cancer diagnosis. This CAREER-award-sponsored project has been seeking to construct new biosensor systems through integration of emerging two-dimensional (2D) nanoelectronic and optoelectronic materials into nano/microfluidic components. Since 2015, this projects has made a series of relevant scientific and technical breakthroughs. The most important achievements include (1) development of a new device fabrication technology, dubbed as nanoimprint-assisted shear exfoliation (NASE), capable of producing arrays of few-layer or multilayer MoS2 device structures (Fig. 1a); (2) establishment of multi-transistor-biosensor platform for quantifying molecular interaction kinetics (Fig. 1b); (3) development of a novel cycle-wise method for operating 2D-material-based nanoelectronic biosensors in liquid conditions, which can prevent the solution-induced chemical damage to the electrical components of biosensing systems (Fig. 1c); (4) identification of new abnormal multiple charge memory states in exfoliated few-layer WSe2 Transistors and Sensors (Fig. 2a); (5) demonstration and in-depth investigation of new memristive states in 2D MoS2 devices with analogue and discrete switching behaviors, which affects the biosensing signals from MoS2 and other 2D material biosensors (Fig. 2b); (6) fabrication of pre-bent MoS2 biosensors on flexible substrates, which is suitable for wearable biosensing applications; (7) create a plasma doping process capable of generating movable sulfur vacancies in MoS2 layers and fabricating analogue memristors and sensors.

 

Intellectual Merits:  The nanoelectronics/microfluidics-integrated biosensors based on emerging atomically layered 2D materials, created in this project, have enabled rapid (lapsed time < 10min), femtomolar-level label-free detection/quantification of low-abundant biomarker molecules. Such sensing devices in combination with new operation methods also enable single-cell immunofunctional analysis for real-time immune status monitoring. The array-type chips of such sensors in combination with our mini-size printed circuit board (PCB) systems allows for more precise diagnosis and stratification of infectious diseases, and drastically reduce the total assay time by at least one order of magnitude as compared to the conventional assay using the ELISA gold standard technique. The detection mechanisms developed in this project are purely electrical, electronic, or optoelectronic. Such device aspects can eliminate the demand for bulky and expensive off-chip optical and electronic instruments required for conventional immunoassays, therefore facilitating us to overcome practical constraints currently hindering the translation of any laboratory-based protoptypes to clinical modules. There are many global health issues such that millions die from easily preventable diseases owing to a lack of appropriate point-of-care (POC) diagnostic tools, including the fast diagnostic systems for current COVID-19 pandemic. The biosensor platform developed in this project, in combination with the circuits developed here, can be operated in the form of a handheld electronic module in POC settings. This opens a door to develop new systems capable of rapid, material/time-saving assay capable of translating cutting-edge fundamental research in the lab to practical applications in various clinical conditions.

 

Broader Impacts: Beyond advancing nanoelectronics, nanofluidics, biosensing technology and pioneering academic research capabilities, this project has broadly contributed to other relevant areas such as (1) nanomanufacturing of 2D-layer-based materials and structures, (2) micro/nanofluidic and eletrohydrodynamic processes for manipulating biological species in a controllable fashion, (3) condensed matter physics for understanding the effects of target-molecule-induced disturbance potentials (or complicated charging/discharging events) on electronic states in 2D layered materials, (4) new device characterization approaches capable of measuring electrical/electronic signals in various ambient conditions, (5) new memristive devices with reconfigurable analogue/digital states, which could be further investigated and exploited for constructing new neuromorphic computing systems or neural networks for mimicking brain activities, (6) new system-level circuit designs that aims at operating emerging 2D material based devices in a portable configuration. In terms of education and training, the project has initiated the thesis work of three Ph.D students. In addition, this NSF-sponsored project has also offered undergraduate and K-12 students valuable research experience for their career development, and also plays an important role in encouraging and attracting talented students in the field of science and engineering.
